Overall, as drought stress intensifies, ranging from a scale of 0 to 1, the resilience of vegetation correspondingly diminishes (Fig. 4d). The karst regions of southwest China (CK) exhibit the most significant response to drought stress (Fig. 4d–f). Notably, the response of karst vegetation in Southwest China (RI mean = 0.23) to drought is considerably higher than that in the karst areas of the Missouri (RI mean = 0.10) and France (RI mean = 0.05), across diverse time scales (Fig. 4e). The response level of vegetation in non-karst areas of southwest China (C) remains around 0.2, whereas it consistently exceeds this in the karst regions of Southwest China. In contrast, karst areas in Missouri and France exhibit lower response levels compared to their respective non-karst areas (Fig. 4e). This pattern suggests that the drought adaptability of vegetation in Southwest China’s karst regions is relatively weaker than in non-karst areas.Fig. 4: Vegetation response to droughts in different karst areas.a–c Three typical case areas: Southwest China, Missouri in the United States, and France; d, f The stability of RI differences with drought thresholds of 0 and 0.5 with different datasets; e RI heterogeneity at different time scales; g Heterogeneity of RI hysteresis at different time scales. The abbreviations in the legend are: Southwest China’s karst (CK) and non karst areas (C), Missouri’s karst (AK) and non karst areas (A), and France’s karst (FK) and non karst areas (F).Full size imageIn addition, with the extension of the drought index’s time scale, RI values across various regions generally exhibit a declining trend. Notably, the rate of this decline varies by region, following the sequence from lowest to highest: Southwest China, Missouri, and then France. Even when drought extends to a year-long scale, the response in Southwest China remains most severe, indicating a lack of adaptability to drought at various time scales. Conversely, vegetation response in Missouri demonstrates a decrease to below 0.1, reflecting robust adaptability to prolonged droughts. In France’s karst region, vegetation has fully adapted to long-term drought conditions. The lag time in Southwest China remains relatively stable, while in both Missouri and France, there is a sharp increase after four months, followed by stabilization (Fig. 4g). For short-term droughts (lasting less than 4 months), the lag time is the greatest in Southwest China, followed by Missouri and France. However, during prolonged droughts (lasting more than 4 months), the order reverses to France > Missouri > China. This variation highlights that China’s karst vegetation is highly sensitive and less adaptable to drought at different time scales, whereas vegetation in Missouri and France is more resilient, particularly against long-term drought conditions.Attribution of differences in vegetation drought responseIn examining the distinct responses and adaptability of vegetation to drought in different karst areas, we considered the influence of several factors, including forest age, canopy height, terrain slope, precipitation, and human population. Our findings reveal that there are significant disparities in the influencing factors across the studied regions (Fig. 5a–e). Notably, forests in southwest China are generally younger compared to those in Missouri and France, particularly in the karst regions (Fig. 5a). In addition, the forests in southwest China are situated in areas with steeper slopes and are encompassed by larger human populations. Further analysis indicates that forest age, canopy height, and terrain slope negatively impact the RI. Increasing forest age and canopy height can enhance adaptability. Specifically, the contributions of forest age, canopy height, and slope to adaptability are 16.67, 1.96, and 18.87%, respectively (Fig. 5h). Conversely, climate characteristics and human disturbance positively affect RI, implying a detrimental impact on adaptability. Specifically, precipitation and population density reduce vegetation adaptability by 31.27% and 31.22%, respectively. Overall, the primary influences on vegetation’s RI to drought in karst areas are forest age, slope, precipitation, and human disturbance, with their average contributions across scales being -16.67, 18.87, 32.27, and 31.22%, respectively. The relatively younger forests in southwest China, combined with significant impacts of precipitation and human activities, result in a lag in the ecological succession of its vegetation ecosystems compared to those in France and Missouri.Fig. 5: Attribution of differences in vegetation drought response in global karst areas.a average forest age distribution among the three typical regions; b–e Differences in forest canopy height, population, precipitation, and slope in the typical regions. f The impact of different factors on RI at pixel scale, where all selected pixels involve karst areas; g The contribution of different factors to the difference in RI index. The abbreviations in the legend are: Southwest China’s karst (CK) and non karst areas (C), Missouri’s karst (AK) and non karst areas (A), and France’s karst (FK) and non karst areas (F).Full size imageDiscussionWe assessed the vegetation response of diverse karst ecosystems to climate events on a global scale. This assessment aids in evaluating the adaptability to drought events and the ecological vulnerability of these fragile regions. We found that the RI decreases across different karst regions worldwide, albeit with varying spatial patterns and magnitudes. This aligns with other studies indicating a global trend of vegetation greening in karst regions9,10,11,12. Moreover, the escalation of global drought events underscores the need for continued attention to the adaptability of vegetation in karst areas5. However, our findings highlight significant regional differences in the RI during periods of rapid vegetation greening and increasing drought events. Global droughts have intensified vegetation responses in both dryland and humid regions, leading to hotspots of intensive response under water deficits. Despite a global trend of reduced response over the past two decades, possibly due to climate-induced and land cover change-induced ‘Earth greening’26,27, vegetation in dryland and karst regions still shows an intense response to perennial water imbalance.Our study also underscores the considerable impact of short-term drought on vegetation in humid and sub-humid regions. The adaptive mechanisms, such as the growth of karst plant roots and deep-water utilization in the vadose zone, are critical in these regions. While global greenness, enhanced by ecological engineering efforts and rising atmospheric CO2 levels, may offset some vegetation loss due to drought, the increasing prevalence of drought poses a significant threat to fragile karst vegetation15. In a broader context, the response levels of different karst regions are influenced by the global distribution of water and heat. However, exceptions exist, such as in the southwest subtropical monsoon humid region of China, characterized by its unique monsoon climate factors and carbonate rock coverage15,28. This region experiences frequent seasonal heatwaves and rapid negative feedback responses to water deficits8. Additionally, factors like shallow soil layers, limited water holding capacity, and substantial soil seepage and erosion, compounded by young, artificially planted forests, render the vegetation in global karst regions highly susceptible to extreme drought stress.It is noteworthy that ecosystems with higher forest age and canopy height exhibit stronger adaptability to drought29. As the vegetation restoration time in karst regions around the world increases, the RI of vegetation to drought events continues to decline. It is undeniable that the vegetation in many karst areas still has a high RI to drought. This implies the necessity of minimizing ecological disturbances rather than merely repairing them post-disturbance30. Contrary to some studies28 suggesting that artificial forests in southwest China have stronger drought resistance, our findings indicate that long-term stable forests (forest age>100) have higher drought adaptability compared to short-term artificially restored forests (forest age<50). This conclusion, however, does not negate previous findings but rather provides a broader perspective, considering our long-term time series study. The results highlight the need to truly reduce ecological disturbance, rather than repair it after disturbance. The natural vegetation ecosystem in karst areas needs to be protected, while disturbed vegetation needs to be repaired in a timely manner and maintained for a long time.Continued global warming has increased the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events1, profoundly impacting terrestrial ecosystems2,3. Our research has found that the phenomenon of vegetation greening does not necessarily equate to adaptation to climate change, particularly in response to drought disturbances. Drought, the most prevalent extreme climate event worldwide4,5, poses a significant threat to fragile terrestrial ecosystems6. In Asia, extensive ecological restoration projects have contributed to greening but have also led to incomplete and unstable ecosystem succession9,10,11,12. In contrast, the forest ecosystems that have been restored for over 100 years in North America and Europe demonstrate strong adaptability to drought disturbances. The adaptability of vegetation in karst areas to drought is predominantly influenced by forest age, precipitation, and human disturbance31,32. Compared to the lower population density in North America and Europe, the higher human activity in China exacerbates the vulnerability of the vegetation in karst areas to disturbance. By quantifying the contributions of forest age and anthropogenic factors to drought adaptability, this study provides actionable insights for prioritizing conservation efforts in vulnerable karst regions, such as protecting short-term artificial vegetation restoration in densely populated areas. With growing evidence suggesting an increase in frequency and intensity of climate extremes5, reducing the response of vegetation to extreme drought and enhancing its stability and adaptability in karst areas has become crucial. It is necessary to enhance the adaptability to drought events through the protection and sustainable management of aging forests. Therefore, reducing ecosystem disturbance and promoting sustainable ecosystem succession are crucial for enhancing drought adaptability in vulnerable ecosystems like those in karst landscapes.The main contribution of this work is the evaluation of differences in vegetation adaptability to drought events in karst areas worldwide, and the quantification of the contributing factors to these differences. Vegetation in karst areas worldwide is greening, while the frequency and duration of drought events are also increasing. Although vegetation adaptability in global karst areas shows an increasing trend, there are significant regional differences in the decreasing rate of RI, with the temperate karst regions exhibiting a drought adaptability improvement rate twice as fast as the global average. Compared to North America and Western Europe, the RI index of karst areas in southwestern China is higher than that of non-karst areas in all types of droughts. Although different regions have shown weak adaptability for short-term sudden drought events, the adaptability of southwest China is significantly weaker than that of Europe and North America for long-term drought. Our research demonstrates that the adaptability of vegetation in karst areas to drought is mainly influenced by forest age (improved: 16.67%), slope (degraded: 18.87%), precipitation (degraded: 32.27%), and population (degraded: 31.22%) disturbance. There is a large amount of ecological restoration vegetation in the karst areas of southwestern China, with an average tree age of around 40 years, much lower than that in the Americas and Europe. These conclusions indirectly indicate that karst ecosystems with more complete ecological succession and longer duration exhibit strong adaptability to drought. Therefore, we suggest that enhancing the adaptability of karst ecosystems to drought events requires truly reducing ecological disturbances, rather than restoring them after disturbances.While this study provides valuable insights into vegetation drought adaptability in global karst regions, several limitations should be noted. The reliance on MODIS NDVI data may not fully capture long-term vegetation dynamics or shorter-term physiological responses, as NDVI can saturate in dense canopies and is influenced by non-vegetation factors like soil background. The drought indices used, such as SPEI and PDSI, though widely accepted, incorporate uncertainties from spatial resolution constraints, potentially affecting localized accuracy. Meanwhile, the differences between different drought datasets can also pose difficulties in defining drought events and may bring uncertainty to the calculation of RI. Additionally, ecological restoration’s long-term impacts require further validation, as the 19-year timeframe may be insufficient to assess fully matured ecosystem resilience. Addressing these limitations could enhance future research through multi-sensor data fusion, higher-resolution climate models, and longer-term observational studies.MethodsMulti-scale meteorological drought indicesSPEI and PDSI33,34,35 based on the water balance equation are widely used to characterize surface dryness. The SPEI index has a multi-scale sequence ranging from 1–48 month since 1901, applicable to global land surface water availability analysis.The 0.5° × 0.5° SPEI v2.6 data36 used in this study is produced using CRU Ts4.03 monthly precipitation and potential evapotranspiration grid data based on FAO-56 Penman-Monteith Estimation. The PDSI is based on Thornthwaite-Mather water balance model from (1/24°) monthly Terra-Climate dataset37, which is calculated based on high-spatial resolution WorldClim meteorological grid data, as well as coarser-spatial resolution but time-varying CRU Ts4.0 and Japanese 55-year Reanalysis (JRA55). 1–12 month time-scale SPEIs from 2001 to 2019 were obtained in NetCDF format and converted to multi-band image in TIFF format for further process in Google Earth Engine. PDSI of the same period was available at the Earth Engine Data catalog.PDSI has been confirmed as a similar proxy to 9–19 month SPEI for qualified mid- and long timescale drought in China38, thus was selected as a comparison. Monthly multi-scale SPEIs and PDSI have positive values representing water surplus and negative values for water deficit, and were used to reflect seasonal drought and prolonged dry/wet conditions. The 0.5° SPEIs and 1/24° PDSI was aggregated to 1 × 1 km using nearest resampling method. \({SPEI}01\), \({SPEI}02\) and \({SPEI}03\) mainly describe short-term drought stress caused by seasonal water loss, such as decreased rainfall or enhanced evaporation in a certain month. \({SPEI}04\), \({SPEI}05\) and \({SPEI}06\) focus on the characterization of soil water conditions, such as soil drying due to reduced precipitation; \({SPEI}07\) to \({SPEI}09\) and \({PDSI}\) have the ability of medium and long-term drought monitoring38, focusing on describing hydrological drought stress, such as river runoff reduction and groundwater level reduction. In contrast, \({SPEI}10\), \({SPEI}11\) and \({SPEI}12\) with longer time scales are conducive to describing the persistent or periodic changes of the local long-term dry/wet climate conditions, such as abnormally dry or wet years caused by El Nino and La Nina.Atmospheric dryness indicatorVapor pressure (VP) represents the maximum water vapor content that the air can hold at a certain temperature, reflecting the potential water-holding capacity of the atmosphere. Water vapor theoretically increases with temperature, while actual moisture in the atmosphere may fail to reach the saturated content due to the insufficient water supply. Vapor pressure deficit (VPD), the difference between the saturated and the actual VP, plays an important role in regulating vegetation physiological processes such as transpiration and photosynthesis. High VPD leads to a decrease in stomatal conductance and limits plant photosynthesis, thus becoming an important proxy reflecting the ecosystem evapotranspiration process, water use efficiency and vegetation carbon cycle. It is an effective index to identify atmospheric water balance and global drought stress39,40. VPD, like PDSI, can be obtained from the Terra-Climate weather grid dataset37.Soil moisture dataSoil Moisture (SM) is the main source of water for vegetation growth. Soil water deficit is caused by changes in the ground water balance due to reduction in precipitation supply and increase in soil evaporation. The SM data products at the global scale have high consistency in the spatial pattern and trend of drought monitoring41. Here, we adopt three SM data in the research period. ERA5-land is a reanalysis dataset based on weather-driven data from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF), released by Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) Climate Date Store (CDS). It provides consistent monthly/hourly global land variables for decades with 0.1° × 0.1° resolution, which can accurately describe past and current climate conditions.SM data comes from the volume water content of four layers of soil provided by the Surface Model in ECMWF Integrated Forecasting System, which are layer1: 0 ~ 7 cm, layer2: 7 ~ 28 cm, layer3: 28 ~ 100 cm, layer4: 100 ~ 289 cm, respectively. Terra-Climate also provides SM products with 1/24° resolution over a long time series. In addition, FLDAS also provides SM percentage data, coming from the surface parameters simulated by Noah 3.6.1 model in Land Data Assimilation System (LDS) of Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET). This set of data improves the meteorological driving data based on Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS), and provides a global monthly 0.1° × 0.1° SM images, including 0 ~ 10 cm, 10 ~ 40 cm, 40 ~ 100 cm and 100 ~ 200 cm underground SM data. It is available in the Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SeDAC) of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), and provides continuous description and assessment of drought events42.Satellite observation and auxiliary grid dataMODIS-based \({\rm{NDVI}}\) of the 16-day return cycle (MOD13A2.006) from 2001 to 2019 was selected as proxy of global vegetation growth. Land surface temperature (LST) product of 8-day was provided by MOD11A2.006 at 1 km resolution. Global MODIS Land Cover dataset at 500 m resolution for yearly intervals between 2001 and 2019 were used to aggregate land cover types percentages, based on Annual International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme (IGBP) classification. The fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) was acquired based on MOD15A2H V6 8-day composite dataset at 500 m resolution.Global monthly precipitation during 2001 to 2019 was based on fifth-generation ECMWF atmospheric reanalysis (ERA5) dataset. Terrain slope was calculated by the Global Multi-resolution Terrain Elevation Data 2010 (GMTED2010) dataset at 7.5 arc-seconds resolution provided by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA). The distribution of human population for the years 2020 was based on the global Gridded Population of World Version 4 (GPWv4), Revision 11 models on 30 arc-second (approximately 1 km) grid cells. GLAS (Geoscience Laser Altimeter System) provides the 500 m global forest canopy height information of broad-leaved forest, coniferous forest and mixed forest in 2008, available at National Earth System Science Data Center, National Science and Technology Infrastructure of China.Forest age distributions of four plant functional types (PFT) representing the 2000–2010 era, was aggregated using global forest age dataset (GFAD) on a 0.5° × 0.5° grid. The four PFTs contain Needleleaf Evergreen Forest (NEF), Needleleaf Deciduous Forest (NDF), Broadleaf Evergreen Forest (BEF) and Broadleaf Deciduous Forest (BDF). All these raster data have been re-projected into EPSG: 4326 with a resolution of 1 km for consistent analysis. World dryland areas are derived from the Aridity Index (AI) and come from the boundary of the dryland system that defines the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MA), in accordance with the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) definition of Drylands43. The regions included in this data set include ultra-arid, arid, semi-arid, and semi-humid dry types43.Global carbonate rock data and karst ecotypesThe global karst distribution data comes from World Map of Carbonate Rock Outcrops v3.0. This v3.0 revision provides a detailed and upper limit area of exposed karst terrain, which contains carbonate rocks that are susceptible to karstification with abundant but discontinuous or impure traits. Global present-day maps of the Köppen-Geiger climate classification44 at 1 km resolution were used in zoning under current climate change. It divides the world into five major climate zones (tropical, dry zone, temperate zone, cold zone, and polar zone), considering annual and monthly temperature and rainfall season changes, as well as referenceable vegetation distribution. Global Maps of Potential Natural Vegetation (PNV) at 1 km resolution were used to indicate vegetation cover in equilibrium with climate, which includes main types of biome communities, such as forests, shrubs, grasslands, and tundra45. We divide the global karst distribution area into 18 typical karst zones based on the global biological community data and climate distribution types, to distinguish the ecological characteristics and comparatively analysis. Each karst ecotypes maintains the integrity of the geographical distribution and corresponds to the climatic conditions and vegetation types that are as homogeneous in-class and differentiated between-class as possible. As a comparison, the buffer zone within 50 km around the karst area is considered as a non-karst area.RI calculation flowchartThe calculation process of RI starts from inputting the monthly NDVI and drought index. Firstly, to synergistically analyze drought and vegetation indices, we normalized the vegetation index and drought index using standard deviation, and constructed drought anomaly indices (\({{SA}}_{{DAI}}\)) and NDVI anomaly (\({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\)) based on standard deviation. These anomaly index indicate the situation where the current state deviates from the long-term same period level. Based on this anomaly index, we further defined DSW under different drought thresholds. For each pixel-wise DSW, we accordingly delineated a corresponding Vegetation Response Window (VRW) in \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) sequence based on the same onset and duration of DSW. On account of lag-time effect, the DVRW is obtained by delaying this window to the corresponding lag month. Here, we use a monthly delay method to calculate the Pearson correlation coefficient between vegetation index and drought index within DSW to determine the actual delay response time, present the delay months when the maximum correlation coefficient is reached. Finally, the ratio of the pixel mean value in the DSW to the pixel mean value in the DVRW over a period of time was calculated to indicates the response degree of vegetation to drought stress46 (Fig. 6).Fig. 6RI Calculation Flowchart.Full size imageTime series composition and normalizationNDVI were de-clouded according to the quality assessment band to mask could-contaminated pixel areas. Pixel-wise composition method provided by Google Earth Engine (GEE) Code Editor was used to obtain statistical characteristics of images and construct continuous sequence. Composited time-series images included monthly and annual \({NDVI}\) sequence composited by Maximum Value Composites (MVC). Impact of vegetation seasonality and climate climatic heterogeneity was removed using z-score based \({NDVI}\) anomaly and meteorological drought index anomaly. We calculated \({NDVI}\) anomaly (Eq. (1)).$${{SA}}_{{NDVI}}=\frac{{{NDVI}}_{i}-\overline{NDV{I}_{i}}}{\sigma \left({NDVI}\right)}$$
                    (1)
                Here, \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) represent \({NDVI}\) anomaly of month \(i\), \({{NDVI}}_{i}\) represent the pixel value of current month \(i\), \(\overline{NDV{I}_{i}}\) and \(\sigma \left({NDVI}\right)\) represent the average and the standard deviation of \({NDVI}\) on month \(i\) over 2001 to 2019, respectively.All of drought anomaly indices (DAI) were normalized by the similar formula, including SPEI, FLDAS, and PDSI (Eq. (2)).$${{SA}}_{{DAI}}=\frac{{{DAI}}_{i}-\overline{DA{I}_{i}}}{\sigma \left({DAI}\right)}$$
                    (2)
                The anomaly indices denote the deviation of the current state from the long-term situation of the same month. \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) signify the magnitude of \(\sigma \left({NDVI}\right)\) that \({{NDVI}}_{i}\) deviates from \(\overline{NDV{I}_{i}}\). Specifically, positive value of \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) indicates that vegetation grows better than that of the same period; negative value of \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) indicate vegetation degradation under the environmental stress; positive value of \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03}\) represents water surplus, while negative value of \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03}\) represents water deficit. Tendency of NDVI was computed by Sen’s slope estimator47.Drought Stress WindowTo measure the effects of intensities of drought on vegetation, we used the negative deviation value of \({\overline{SPEI03}}_{i}\) from its annual level to represent different DSW (Supplementary Fig. 11). We consider \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03} < 0\) as drought starts. The \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03} < -0.5\) was recognized as moderate drought indicating that current \({{SPEI}03}_{i}\) is 1/2 times \(\sigma \left({SPEI}03\right)\) below the value of \(\overline{SPEI03_i}\). The \({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03} < -1\) denoted severe drought where \({{SPEI}03}_{i}\) is one \(\sigma \left({SPEI}03\right)\) lower than the average level of month \(i\) in other years. The thresholds were chosen to ensure that widespread global drought events can be well captured. Drought events occur continuously over time and space, so we defined negative \({{SPEI}03}_{i}\) detected for 3 consecutive months as one DSW occurrence based on monthly data. Consecutive identification and division of negative month allows us to find out the DSWs for each year or over the whole time period, and calculated its traits of multi-scale drought occurrence. The same approach is applicable to other drought indices.Delayed vegetation response windowsDue to global hydrothermal variability and terrestrial ecosystem heterogeneity, the response of vegetation to climate has latitudinal and local time-lag effects in spatial pattern, which reflects the important interaction of vegetation growth and climate change controlled by micro-physiological adjustment and macro-pattern distribution48. Taking into account the time lag effect is of great importance for prediction and assessment of vegetation dynamics under global climate change48. Pearson correlation was calculated between \({{NDVI}}_{d}\) and \({SPEI}03\) (Eq. (3)).$${r}_{{{NDVI}}_{d},{SPEI}03}=\frac{{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}\left({{{NDVI}}_{d}}_{i}-\overline{NDV{I}_{{d}_{i}}}\right)\left({{SPEI}03}_{i}-\overline{SPEI03}\right)}{\sqrt{{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}{\left({{{NDVI}}_{d}}_{i}-\overline{NDV{I}_{{d}_{i}}}\right)}^{2}{\sum }_{i=1}^{n}{\left({{SPEI}03}_{i}-\overline{SPEI03}\right)}^{2}}}$$
                    (3)
                here \({{NDVI}}_{d}\) represents \({NDVI}\) with \(d\) month delayed; \(\overline{NDV{I}_{{d}_{i}}}\) means the mean value among all \(i\) months in the time period. The \(d\) varies from 0 to 6 months and the pixel-wise lag month was marked as \(d\) with the highest determination coefficient (\({{r}_{{{NDVI}}_{d},{SPEIs}}}^{2}\)). The same calculation process was applied to other drought indices, to figure out lag time between vegetation and drought climate.Vegetation response to drought stressFor each pixel-wise DSW, we accordingly delineated a corresponding Vegetation Response Window (VRW) in \({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}\) sequence based on the same onset and duration of DSW. On account of lag-time effect, the DVRW is obtained by delaying this window to the corresponding lag month. Therefore, the ratio of the pixel mean value in the DSW to the pixel mean value in the DVRW over a period of time was calculated to indicates the response degree of vegetation to drought stress46 (Eq. (4)). The RI index calculated based on different drought datasets has high consistency, indicating that this method has high reliability (Fig. S13).$${{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}}=\frac{{\rm{mean}}({{SA}}_{{NDVI}}{\rm{in\; D}}{\rm{VR}}{\rm{Ws}})}{{\rm{mean}}\left({{SA}}_{{SPEI}03}{\rm{in\; DSW}}{\rm{s}}\right)}$$
                    (4)
                Here \({{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}}\) denotes the vegetation Response Index under drought stress, \(\Delta\) refers to drought intensity and \({\rm{T}}\) means a specific period. Since the denominator is always determined negative, \({{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}} > 0\) indicates that vegetation is significantly impaired under drought stress, and \({{\rm{RI}}}_{\Delta ,{\rm{T}}} < 0\) illustrates that vegetation remains stable or grows better when drought occurs. The same quantitative process was calculated for all drought indices for a comprehensive analysis.Calculation of the contribution of different factorsPartial regression coefficients indicated the sensitivity of RI to different factors. This method has been widely used in detecting different factors, which can effectively derive the effect of a single factor by removing the collinearity impacts of other controlling factors. Based on SPSS 22.0, we calculated the sensitivity coefficients of impact factors at different scales from pixel scales.$${RI}=\Delta +\mathop{\sum }\limits_{i=1}^{6}{S}_{i}\times {F}_{i}$$
                    (5)
                where \({F}_{i}\) represents different factors, with \({F}_{1}\)-\({F}_{6}\) representing forest age, forest canopy height, precipitation, population, DEM, and slope, respectively. \({S}_{i}\) represents the sensitivity coefficient of RI to different factors. \(\triangle\) is the intercept of the multiple linear regression model.Finally, we estimated the influences of different factors on RI trends by multiplying the sensitivities with RI trends. The influences of forest age, forest canopy height, precipitation, population, and slope on RI are represented by \({T}_{a}\), \({T}_{h}\), \({T}_{{Pre}}\), \({T}_{{Pou}}\), and \({T}_{{slop}}\) respectively. The DEM factor is automatically removed by the model when calculating partial correlation parameters in SPSS 22.0. Therefore, the DEM indicator is not included in subsequent calculations. The sum of all effects of different factors on RI difference indicated by \({T}_{{all}}\). The percentage (%) of relative contribution of different factors (\({{\rm{RC}}}_{{\rm{i}}}\)) was calculated as follows:$${T}_{i}={S}_{i}\left(\max \left({F}_{i}\right)-\min \left({F}_{i}\right)\right)$$
                    (6)
                $${T}_{{all}}=\mathop{\sum }\limits_{i=1}^{5}\left|{T}_{i}\right|\,$$
                    (7)
                $${{\rm{RC}}}_{{\rm{i}}}\left( \% \right)=\frac{{T}_{i}}{{T}_{{all}}}\times 100 \%$$
                    (8)
                Here, \({T}_{1}\)-\({T}_{5}\) representing \({T}_{a}\), \({T}_{h}\), \({T}_{{Pre}}\), \({T}_{{Pou}}\), and \({T}_{{slop}}\) respectively. Plus or minus sign of contribution indicate that the factor enhances or alleviates RI, and also indicates that the factor is unfavorable or beneficial for karst vegetation to adapt to drought events. The total value of the absolute contribution (%) was 100%.
